Hello, {{state.$r}}! What would you like to do? 
 
(1) Learn about Facilitation
(2) Learn about Disruptive people
(3) Forget my name
(Please answer with 1-3)
This is the first time we speak 🤖
We already spoke {{state.$r}} times!
Alright, I have forgotten your name.
Hello, I see you've signed up for the Facilitation course. Please, What may I call you?
Try saying something like "forget my name"!
(To see how this works, double-click anywhere on the flow and go to the "Transitions" panel)
testest
Please answer with 1,2 or 3

What type of person would you like to learn more about?
(1) Dominator
(2) Talker
(3)  Prisoner
(4) Expert
(5) Complainer
(6) Dependent
(7) Return to main menu
(Please answer 1-7)
Incorrect input, please answer with 1,2,3,5,6 or 7.

(1) What does a Dominator say?
(2) How does a Dominator behave?
(3) What can you do?
(4) Return to other roles

A Dominator may say things like: 
 
"I've signed more new accounts than anyone in this room"
 
or
 
"That would work if we weren't living in the real world"

A Dominator generally:
 
Let others know how important they are
 

Talk a lot, but are poor listeners

 
Tend to shut other participants out

To handle a Dominator you can:
 
Acknowledge their experience.
 

Encourage them to share the limelight.
 

Ask them to help you gain participation of others.
 
Build confidence of other participants.
Incorrect entry. Please answer with 1,2,3 or 4.
Incorrect input, please answer with 1,2,3 or 4.

(1) What does a Talker say?
(2) How does a Talker behave?
(3) What can you do?
(4) Return to other roles

A Talker may say things like:
 
"Come sit by me! I haven't talked to you in ages!"
 
"Sorry! I had to tell her something really important"
 
"I was listening. He was helping me with the exercise"

A Talker generally: 
 
Talk throughout the session.
 
Involve others in side conversations and outside the room.
 
Seem disinterested in what you have to say.

To handle a talker you can:
 
Draw them into the activity you are leading.
 
Ask them to share ideas with the entire group.
 
Move physically closer to them to draw their attention.
 
Ask them to hold side conversations during the break.

(1) What do Prisoners say?
(2) How do Prisoners behave?
(3) What can you do?
(4) Return to other roles

A Prisoner may say things like:
 
"Couldn't we have done this via conference call? It would have been easier."
 
"I've seen this before. Why do I have to be in this session?"

A Prisoner generally:
 
Arrive late at beginning of session and from breaks.

Seem uninterested.

Make sure everyone realizes the sacrifices they have made to attend the session.

To handle a Prisoner you can:
 
Involve them immediately
 
Ask them for advice on the session or topics.
 
Quote something they said to you during a break to show their value to the session.

(1) What do Experts say?
(2) How do Experts behave?
(3) What can you do?
(4) Return to other roles

An Expert may say things like:
 
"Why would you say that? A thinking person would agree with me."
 
"I wouldn't do it that way. It will never work"

"That's good in theory, but we live in the real world"

An Expert generally:
 
Enjoy challenging your competence
 
Argue with other participants
 
Give you the impression the already know it all

To handle an Expert you can:
 
Call on them early so they do not decide when to challenge you.
 
Acknowledge their comments without agreeing or disagreeing
 
Solicit alternatives from group
 
Spend time during breaks showing you understand their point of view

(1) What do Complainers say?
(2) How do Complainers behave?
(3) What can you do?
(4) Return to other roles

A Complainer may say things like:
 
"This room is freezing. You're cold too, right?"
 
"Why do we have to start at 8.00 am. We're not morning people."
 
"Why do I always have to drive the farthest to these sessions?"

A Complainer generally:
 
Find fault with everything -- food, lighting, agenda and ideas.
 
Vocalize displeasure with everything

Attempt to recruit others in their displeasure

To handle a Complainer you can:
 
Respond to their complaints immediately
 
Ask if others have similar feelings
 
Be tactful and patient with them

(1) What do Dependents say?
(2) How do Dependents behave?
(3) What can you do?
(4) Return to other roles

A Dependent may say things like:
 
"Is that the right answer?"
 
"I agree with Mark, I don't have anything else to add."
 
"I'm not an expert so i don't know if this makes any sense."

A Dependent generally:
 
Lack self confidence
 
Agree with everything and don't seem to express their true opinions
 
Have good ideas if you can illicit them

To handle a Dependent you can:
 
Involve them gradually, beginning with questions they can easily answer
 
Identify opportunities to involve them (e.g., hanging wall charts, distributing handouts)
 
Be available to assist them during small group activities
I have forgotten your name! Speak to me again to start from the beginning.
test
You've chosen Facilitation!
Main

To handle a Dependent you can:
 
Involve them gradually, beginning with questions they can easily answer.
 
Identify opportunities to involve them
 
Be available to assist them during small group activities
You've chosen Disruptive People!

What would you like to do?
(1) Explore the course toolbox
(2) View the teamsite
(3) Listen to a podcast about meeting the person requesting a facilitation
(4)  View the FaQ
(5) Return to the main menu

Have fun!

(2) 1-2-3-All
(3) Rotating Flipcharts
Please answer with 1,2,3,4 or 5.

Here is a link to the podcast. Enjoy!

Free association to elicit descriptions, for example of feeling / situations / future desired states
 
(1) intent or Purpose
(2) Usual or expected outcome
(3) Possible Problems
(4) Facilitator involvement
(5) Resources and Preparation
(6) Return to Toolbox
Used for allowing people to share their feelings through finding a picture that represents how they feel. This is often easier for people that just being asked "Tell me how you feel about..."
Each participant expressing their feelings through a picture.
People cannot find a ‘suitable’ picture – you can have blank paper and pens in reserve so that they can quickly draw their own
Note taking and encouragement.

You need a large space to spread out the pictures - a clean floor is ideal, and a place for people to display their picture - a whiteboard / wall, don't forget magnets or Blu-tack (häftmässa / mounting putty).

A set of around 100  pictures is available on the Facilitator Teamsite - they are divided up into separate PowerPoint files as the size is large.
Please answer with 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 or 6.
Each participant expressing their feelings through a picture.
Please answer with 1-9.

(1) Intent or Purpose
(2) Key Words
(3) Recommended size of group
(4) Expected outcome
(5) return to toolbox

Following breakout groups, there is typically a report-back process when each team presents its results to the other teams. In this process people generally are not as attentive to what other teams are saying: some people may be still preparing their own report-back.
Feedback, involvement, closing, debriefing
As a minimum 3 groups of 2 people, but preferably more.
A deeper understanding of each groups work

1.	Ask people to silently reflect individually on a shared challenge, framed as a question (e.g., What opportunities do YOU see for making progress on this challenge? How would you handle this situation? What ideas or actions do you recommend?) 1 min

2.	Ask them to generate ideas in pairs, building on ideas from self-reflection. 2 min.

3.	Finally, ask them to share and develop ideas from your pair in foursomes (notice similarities and differences). 4 min.

4.	Ask, “What is one idea that stood out in your conversation?” Each group shares one important idea with all (repeat cycle as needed). 5 min.

Identifying the Advantages and possible Disadvantages of a decision

(1) Intent or Purpose
(2) Key Words
(3) Recommended size of group
(4) Expected outcome
(5) Possible Problems
(6) Resources needed
(7) Return to toolbox
Please answer with 1-7.
Allow the group to discuss and identify the advantages and possible disadvantages of a decision, and how increase the chance of the advantages and decrease the disadvantages
Future, advantages, disadvantages, planning, best results, decision consequences
None, but will need 1-2-4-group type organisation for large groups
A set of expected advantages and possible disadvantages to a decision, and how to increase the advantages and prevent or minimize the disadvantages
Heavy discussion against disadvantages by those who are very much for the decison

Flip chart paper, pen and a place to display the Advantages and Diasdvantages and how to increase the advantages and prevent or minimise the disadvantages. You can also use the pictures from "Choose a picture (or two)" activity to help.

Raise the energy in the room and learn something new about your colleagues.

Organize the participants into groups of 8 to 20 people.

Facilitator tells the participants that in the Line Up they will have a chance to learn things about one another they may never think to ask.

Facilitator tells the groups that this is a competition, and that when they are asked to line-up in a particular way the first group to do so wins, so they need to get into the lines as quickly as possible, and clap to show they have finished. 

Example: Tell the groups to line up by height (shortest to tallest) and to all clap when they have finished.

Line Up Suggestions: Shoe size; Length of arms reach; Alphabetically by first name; Order of birthdays from Jan to Dec; Age; Length of time in current position; Number of animals you own.

Each member is given enough time to think about the problem and to speak his/her mind. 

By hearing everyone's point and giving it attention in the following up discussion, the group arrives at a joint conclusion which every group member supports.

Divide the team of four into a core team of two people who start discussing the problem at hand. The two other persons work individually to find new solutions. 

After 10-15 minutes (depending on the complexity of the problem), a the third team member joins the core team by presenting his/her ideas regarding the problem. The core team listens and after the presentation, the three participants discuss the problem among themselves. 

The fourth team member joins. He/she joins in, presents his or her perspective of the problem and the group discusses. Now when all members have joined in, the whole team discusses the problem in order to reach a solution together.

Whole group activity to get everyone to talk to each other and begin to get to know them, or discover something new.

Used at the beginning for a group that do now know each other as a way to exchange names and learn a bit about each other.

Can be used as an energizer with groups that know each other – to discover new things..
Learning names, forming a connection between members of a group.
No one has done the activities on the sheet - check that the sheet contains the right activities for the people in the group.
Minimal: starting up the activity and then making sure that people keep circulating.

pace to mingle
Activity sheets (an example is located in the teamsite toolbox) - you can include unusual items, by asking people beforehand to tell you (and not share with the group) something unusual about them selves that they are willing to share.
